And lo!, after the hit-us-repeatedly-in-the-head-with-a-2 x4 lessons of the last six years, too many still conflate economic success with virtue. While it may be personally satisfying to some who didn't lose their shirts in the Crash, a display of smug is no explanation of what actually happened.

Many borrowers may have behaved foolishly, even foolhardily--but by far the majority of those who lost their homes and meagre savings in the 2008 Crash were just ordinary folks behaving as Americans are expected to behave. They earned less than they needed to live in the manner those acres of advertisements told them they should, so they borrowed the money. Their household income had been falling, so they borrowed more. They only did what their President, in the wake of 9/11 told them to do: keep spending.

Unfortunately, they did all that borrowing at the wrong time. They did it during a bubble in the precise sector, housing, that also housed their equity, when the fundamentals of the economy were weak, when we were borrowing hundreds of billions to pay for the disaster of Iraq, when the banksters were unregulated and when those same banks' wealth was serially invested in worthless paper instruments that no one could rate or understand.

Was there immorality afoot? Was virtue in decline? Maybe so, but that decline did not occur solely or even to a great degree in the millions of foreclosed homes.

Looking for vice? Look at greed rampant. Look at the financiers.

If our universities cannot accomplish such a simple step because they are divided on such a topic, then what you teach to the students isn't either something accurate or agreeable.

Mr. Perkins, can our universities act in a decisive way?

Helplessness and hopelessness are as much symptoms of the constant denial of opportunity poor people face as their bad teeth. Is easy to underestimate the destructive effect of constant struggle on a person's ability to cope. What it amazing is that some people who have regular contact with poor, defeated adults think that the circumstances in which you grew up do not affect your attitude as an adult.

It is not fashionable to point out the simple facts that you cite here. The sad truth of the matter is that people do have the ability to change their lives. To believe otherwise is to deny the human spirit.

Culture always trumps policy.

That does not exonerate the disastrous economic policy proposals offered by Ryan and his party. It just affirms the reality that some people just do not care enough about their life situation to change their behavior to enable them to change their situation. Education is the key to socio economic change and dysfunctional family or personal values do not lend themselves to the work required to obtain an education.

The only thing in their lives that they believe they can be proud of is being born with white (or black or tan or yellow) skin. Those who truly believe that the poor are poor only because they are "lazy takers" are those who managed to avoid poverty by a very few dollars and fear that anyone with a little ambition who is in poverty will take away their ability to stay in the lower rungs of the middle class. Again, they are afraid that their own abilities are not up to the challenges of life. This I fear must also apply to many who use poverty as a political weapon, to convince voters that "they're coming to take away everything you 'earned' that nobody or "nuthing" helped you get.

Well Mr. Blow, I have to be a contrarian here. When your community is poverty stricken, it looks like that's the way things are. You have conspiracy theories as to why some people are better off than you, and do not have the knowledge to get out of it.

From personal experience, the majority of those in poverty that I have met do not have the education to escape. Many of them do not have the work skills to get out of it either. I do not know Mr. Blow if you have actually done any research in such communities, interviewed them, or just studied them.

They will tell you they do not have time to go to the library and find out how to do better, and all they have time to do is work and come home and watch TV. Not that they are dumb, lazy, or unkind, they just do not have the drive to get ahead.

As usual this statement will be challenged, but I am not referring to 100% of the poor, it is the 68% that are in the one standard deviation from the mean. Those who are two deviations below the mean, are those who will pretty much stay there, and those who are two deviations above the mean, are the most likely to get out of poverty.

But in general, it is a cultural thing, that is the way the people they know live, that is their view of reality.

@NYHuguenot

Most young workers don't feel that they need a union until they need one. Having worked on workers' rights and defended people against unlawful firing, I can tell you that even in the public sphere, unions do help their workers. If workers don't feel that they are properly defended they can vote out the current leaders. Problem is in many places union leaders don't get voted out because no one else want to do what is often a thankless job.

Union workers deserve "free choice."

Labor unions should have to earn their dues the old-fashioned way. They should earn them. Unions need to figure out how to become relevant again. In this global economy.

I am so thankful for my union. It has fought for - and gotten - higher compensation and a fair evaluation system for me and all my fellow employees - regardless of whether or not they are union members.

This record of stealing money from employees and forcing them to accept odious working conditions is shameful for a nation as rich as ours. In the past, we had powerful labor unions that looked out for the interests of workers, albeit they sometimes overdid it in the form of "featherbedding," etc. The union movement arose because of the abuses of employers of the Gilded Age: 14 hour days, child labor, employees locked in their work spaces, and such. The unions brought about decent working conditions at decent pay, not only for union members but for employees in general. Now, the unions have been reduced to a shadow of their former selves as states passed so-called "right to work" laws and many manufacturing jobs were sent overseas. The service jobs we have left are mostly non-union, though some service workers are represented by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU). As a result, we're returning to the unethical and even criminal employee practices of the past, aided and abetted by Republican-dominated state governments and employer-friendly outfits like ALEC.

Clearly, service workers in particular need to organize and join a union like SEIC if they're to have any chance to stop the kinds of employer abuse that have arisen and are promoted by right-wing politicians aligned with employer interests. The labor vs. management battles of an earlier era may have to be fought all over again until workers achieve the decent pay and working conditions that they deserve..

AND, conveniently, when the crash finally came, the back offices folded, and the Banks weren't holding any of the debt (the money disappeared).........thus the culprits and the money were long gone and there seemed to be no one accountable.     We all assumed it was the finance industry, and it was!     The problem is that the scam was so well engineered, and the banks were so well insulated that it was impossible to define the crooks or 'claw back' the money.

This is why charging a fee for the amenities makes sense. Nobody is entitled to amenities like exercise rooms and extra storage rooms. But there's a world of difference between being told "sorry, you can't have that because of who you are," versus being told "sorry, the price to use those facilities is $75 a month, if you can pay that we'll give you a pass. If not, sorry."
.
I have experience in this sort of thing. When I started architecture school I used to park in a lot near the architecture building. I paid a fee for an upgraded parking pass, but it was worth it given how far the cheap lots were, and the Texas heat. About a year into it, they changed the policy and stopped allowing students to pay extra and park close. I would have gladly paid the money, but "no," said the administration, "you can't park there because of who you are." It sounds silly, but it really does hurt.
A "reasonable" fee or a "market-based" fee?
